lessons.title: Understanding the Fundamentals
lessons.content:
• Point: Imagine a tiny dot on a piece of paper. This is a point. It's the smallest unit in graphic design.
  • Line: Connect two points, and you have a line. Lines can be straight, curved, or dotted.
  • Shape: A closed line creates a shape. Shapes can be simple like circles and squares, or complex like polygons.

Elements of Design: The Building Blocks

  • Vertices: These are the points where lines meet in a shape. A triangle has three vertices.
  • Edges: The lines that form the boundaries of a shape are called edges.
  • Elements: These are the basic components of a design. They include points, lines, shapes, colors, textures, and typography.

Types of Lines: Adding Structure

  • Straight Lines: These are lines that run in a single direction without curving.
  • Curved Lines: These lines have a bend or curve.
  • Diagonal Lines: These lines are neither horizontal nor vertical.
  • Dotted Lines: These lines are made up of a series of dots.

Shapes: The Building Blocks of Form

  • Geometric Shapes: These are shapes with precise, mathematical definitions, such as squares, circles, and triangles.
  • Organic Shapes: These shapes are more irregular and resemble natural forms, like leaves or clouds.

Color: The Language of Design

  • Color Theory: This is the study of how colors interact and affect our perception.
  • Color Wheel: A circular arrangement of colors that shows relationships between them.
  • Primary Colors: Red, yellow, and blue are the primary colors because all other colors can be created by mixing them.
  • Secondary Colors: Orange, green, and purple are created by mixing two primary colors.

lessons.title: Typography: The Language of Design
lessons.content:
• Serif Fonts: These fonts have small lines (serifs) at the ends of their strokes. They are often used for body text because they are easier to read. Examples include Times New Roman, Georgia, and Garamond.
  • Sans-Serif Fonts: These fonts lack serifs. They are often used for headlines, titles, and branding because they are clean and modern. Examples include Helvetica, Arial, and Roboto.
  • Script Fonts: These fonts mimic handwritten styles. They are often used for invitations, logos, and branding. Examples include Calligraphia and Pacifico.

Key Typographic Elements

  • Font Family: A group of fonts that share a similar design.
  • Font Weight: The thickness of a font's strokes.
  • Font Style: The slant or italicization of a font.
  • Leading: The vertical space between lines of text.
  • Tracking: The horizontal space between letters.
  • Kerning: The adjustment of space between specific pairs of letters.

Typography and Readability

  • Legibility: How easy a font is to read.
  • Readability: How comfortable a font is to read for extended periods.
  • Contrast: The difference between light and dark elements in a design.

Typography and Design

  • Hierarchy: The arrangement of elements in a design based on their importance.
  • Alignment: The placement of elements on a page.
  • Grids: A system of lines used to organize elements on a page.

lessons.title: Design Principles: The Rules of Composition
lessons.content:
• Balance: Creating visual harmony by arranging elements symmetrically or asymmetrically.
  • Symmetrical Balance: Elements are arranged equally on both sides of an axis to create a sense of order.
  • Asymmetrical Balance: Elements are arranged unevenly, creating visual interest and dynamism.
  • Contrast: Using different elements, such as color or size, to create emphasis.
  • Repetition: Repeating design elements to create unity and consistency.
  • Proximity: Grouping related items together to create visual relationships.
  • Alignment: Aligning elements along a common axis to create structure and clarity.
  • White Space: The use of empty space to help balance the layout and improve readability.

lessons.title: Color Theory: The Language of Design
lessons.content:
• Color Wheel: A circular arrangement of colors that shows relationships between them. Primary colors are red, yellow, and blue, and secondary colors are orange, green, and purple.
  • Analogous Colors: Colors that are next to each other on the color wheel and create harmony.
  • Complementary Colors: Colors that are opposite each other on the color wheel, creating strong contrast.
  • Color Psychology: Different colors can evoke different emotions (e.g., red for excitement, blue for calm).
  • Color Harmony: The use of color schemes like analogous, complementary, or triadic to achieve a visually pleasing composition.

lessons.title: Typography: The Art of Choosing and Arranging Type
lessons.content:
• Serif Fonts: Fonts with small lines (serifs) at the ends of their strokes. These are typically used for body text. Examples include Times New Roman and Georgia.
  • Sans-Serif Fonts: Fonts without serifs. These are typically used for headings and titles. Examples include Arial and Helvetica.
  • Script Fonts: Fonts that mimic handwriting, often used for invitations or special designs. Examples include Pacifico and Calligraphia.
  • Monospace Fonts: Fonts where each character occupies the same width, often used for coding. Examples include Courier New.
  • Hierarchy: Establishing a visual order in your text, ensuring that the most important information stands out.
  • Kerning: Adjusting the spacing between individual letters to improve readability.
  • Tracking: Adjusting the overall spacing between letters across a word or paragraph.
  • Leading: The vertical spacing between lines of text.

lessons.title: UI/UX Design: Designing for User Experience
lessons.content:
• UI (User Interface) Design: Focuses on the look and feel of a product’s interface. This includes elements such as buttons, layouts, and colors.
  • UX (User Experience) Design: Focuses on the overall experience a user has when interacting with a product, ensuring that it is intuitive and easy to use.
  • Wireframing: Creating simple sketches or diagrams of an interface to lay out the basic structure before adding design elements.
  • Prototyping: Creating an interactive version of the design to test how users will interact with it.
  • Responsive Design: Ensuring the design works well on a variety of screen sizes, from mobile phones to desktops.
  • Usability Testing: Testing a product with real users to identify potential issues and areas for improvement.

lessons.title: Design Trends: Staying Up-to-Date
lessons.content:
• Minimalism: A design style focused on simplicity, using minimal elements to create a clean, modern look.
  • Flat Design: A two-dimensional design style that avoids gradients and shadows. It emphasizes simplicity and clarity.
  • Neumorphism: A design trend that combines flat design with subtle 3D elements, using soft shadows and highlights to create a quasi-3D look.
  • Dark Mode: A design style that uses a dark background with lighter text and elements, popular for reducing eye strain and creating a modern look.
  • Gradient Colors: A smooth transition between colors, used to add depth and interest to designs.
  • Geometric Shapes: Using bold and modern geometric shapes to create structure and balance in a design.

lessons.title: Types of Graphic Design
lessons.content:
• Print Design: Focuses on designing materials that will be printed, such as brochures, business cards, and packaging.
  • Digital Design: Includes designing for websites, mobile apps, social media, and email newsletters.
  • Logo Design: Creating unique and memorable logos for brands, often a critical part of a brand's identity.
  • UI/UX Design: Designing user interfaces and experiences for digital products like websites and apps.
  • Motion Graphics: Combining animation, video, and sound to create engaging, dynamic content for presentations, websites, and advertisements.

lessons.title: Motion Graphics: Bringing Designs to Life
lessons.content:
• Animation: The process of creating movement by displaying a series of still images or objects in rapid succession.
  • Keyframing: Setting specific points in an animation where changes in motion or appearance occur.
  • Tweening: Automatically generating intermediate frames between keyframes to create smooth transitions.
  • Timing: Controlling the speed and duration of an animation to create the desired effect.
  • Easing: Adjusting the speed of motion to make it feel more natural.
  • Types of Motion Graphics: Explainer videos, logo animations, social media animations, and interactive animations are popular types of motion graphics used in design.

lessons.title: Color in Design: The Power of Color
lessons.content:
• Color Psychology: Different colors evoke different emotions and have psychological effects. For example, red is often associated with energy and passion, while blue is associated with calm and trust.
  • Color Palette: A set of colors chosen for a design project to maintain visual consistency.
  • Contrast: The difference between light and dark colors to make elements stand out.
  • Color Accessibility: Ensuring your color choices are accessible to users with color blindness by using sufficient contrast and other techniques.
  • Color and Branding: Colors play a crucial role in a brand’s identity and can evoke specific associations in the audience.

lessons.title: Print Design vs. Digital Design
lessons.content:
• Print Design: Focuses on designing for physical products like brochures, business cards, posters, and packaging.
  • Resolution: Print designs require higher resolution (300 DPI or more) for clarity, while digital designs typically have lower resolution (72 DPI or 96 DPI) for screens.
  • Color Profiles: Print designs use the CMYK color profile, while digital designs use the RGB color profile.
  • File Formats: Print designs are often saved as PDF or TIFF, while digital designs use formats like JPEG, PNG, and GIF.
  • Responsiveness: Digital designs must adapt to different screen sizes, whereas print designs are fixed in size.

lessons.title: Design for Accessibility: Making Designs Inclusive
lessons.content:
• Color Accessibility: Ensuring sufficient contrast between text and background colors to help people with color blindness or low vision.
  • Web Accessibility Standards: Following guidelines like WCAG to make websites accessible to people with disabilities, including providing alt text for images and ensuring keyboard navigability.
  • Font Size and Readability: Using larger fonts and adjustable text size to make content readable for people with visual impairments.
  • Accessible Forms: Designing forms that are easy to fill out for users with mobility or cognitive impairments, with clear labels and error messaging.
  • Testing for Accessibility: Using tools and conducting user testing to ensure your design meets accessibility standards.

lessons.title: Responsive Design: Adapting to Different Screens
lessons.content:
• Fluid Grids: Using percentages instead of fixed pixel values to ensure layouts adjust to different screen sizes.
  • Media Queries: CSS rules that apply styles based on the size of the screen, ensuring that designs look good on mobile, tablet, and desktop devices.
  • Flexible Images: Ensuring that images scale properly across different screen sizes by using max-width and other CSS properties.
  • Mobile-First Design: Designing the mobile version of a site first and progressively enhancing it for larger screens.
  • Testing Responsiveness: Testing your design on various devices and screen sizes to ensure a seamless experience for users.

lessons.title: Tools and Software for Graphic Design
lessons.content:
• Adobe Photoshop: A powerful tool for editing photos and creating digital designs with advanced features for professionals.
  • Adobe Illustrator: A vector graphics editor used for creating logos, illustrations, and complex designs.
  • Sketch: A popular tool for UI/UX designers focused on creating user interfaces and interactive prototypes.
  • Figma: A cloud-based design tool used for collaborative UI/UX design, allowing teams to work together in real-time.
  • Canva: An easy-to-use tool for creating simple designs like social media posts, presentations, and infographics, suitable for beginners.
